unnormalised: The price of petrol these days, yaar! It's enough to make you consider walking all the way from Delhi to Mumbai. I remember when I first started driving, petrol was, like, Rs. 35/litre. Now, it's hovering around Rs. 105 per liter in Mumbai! My poor wallet weeps more than a Bollywood heroine during a separation scene.
normalised: The price of petrol these days, yaar! It's enough to make you consider walking all the way from Delhi to Mumbai. I remember when I first started driving, petrol was, like, rupee thirty five per liter. Now, it's hovering around rupee one hundred and five per liter in Mumbai! My poor wallet weeps more than a Bollywood heroine during a separation scene.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the mileage. My uncle, a retired govt. official, swears his old Ambassador used to give him 20 kmpl, but I suspect he's exaggerating. My modern car, with all its fancy gadgets, barely manages 12 kmpl in city traffic. Maybe I should trade it in for a bicycle, but then I'd have to deal with the potholes and the auto-rickshaws. It's a lose-lose situation!
normalised: And don't even get me started on the mileage. My uncle, a retired government official, swears his old Ambassador used to give him twenty kilometer per liter, but I suspect he's exaggerating. My modern car, with all its fancy gadgets, barely manages twelve kilometer per liter in city traffic. Maybe I should trade it in for a bicycle, but then I'd have to deal with the potholes and the auto-rickshaws. It's a lose-lose situation!

unnormalised: Seriously, I’ve started measuring my car’s fuel efficiency in terms of cups of chai I could buy with the same amount of money. One liter of petrol equals approximately 10 cups of chai. Think about that! Ten glorious cups of chai versus a measly 12 km of driving. The choice is clear, isn't it? Okay, maybe not when I have to drive to the office, but still...

unnormalised: The other day, I saw a guy pushing his car. I thought he'd run out of petrol, but he said he was trying to improve his fuel efficiency. He claimed he was getting, like, 0.01 kmpl that way. I didn't have the heart to tell him that it probably wasn't worth the effort, considering the cost of new shoes.

He claimed he was getting, like, zero point zero one kilometer per liter that way. I didn't have the heart to tell him that it probably wasn't worth the effort, considering the cost of new shoes.

unnormalised: In conclusion, dealing with rising fuel prices is a national sport these days. Perhaps the government should consider giving us fuel-efficiency awards or something. Maybe a certificate that says, "Congratulations, you've managed to drive your car without declaring bankruptcy." Now that's something I’d hang on my wall!
